name: yourself
content:
yourself

pronoun
 
 
/jɔːˈself/, weak form
 
/jəˈself/
 
/jɔːrˈself/,
 
/jʊrˈself/, weak form
 
/jərˈself/
(plural yourselves
 
/jɔːˈselvz/, weak form
 
/jəˈselvz/
 
/jɔːrˈselvz/,
 
/jʊrˈselvz/, weak form
 
/jərˈselvz/
)
Idioms
jump to other results
  1.  
     (the reflexive form of you) used when the person or people being spoken to both cause and are affected by an action
    • Have you hurt yourself?
    • You don't seem quite yourself today (= you do not seem well or do not seem as happy as usual).
    • Enjoy yourselves!
  2.  
     used to emphasize the fact that the person who is being spoken to is doing something
    • Do it yourself—I don't have time.
    • You can try it out for yourselves.
    • You yourself are one of the chief offenders.
  3. used instead of ‘you’ in order to sound polite or formal (although some people do not consider this use to be correct)
    • We sell a lot of these to people like yourself.
    • ‘And yourself,’ he replied, ‘How are you?’
Idioms
be yourself
  1. to act naturally
    • Don't act sophisticated—just be yourself.
(all) by yourself/yourselves
  1. alone; without anyone else
    • How long were you by yourself in the house?
    Which Word? alone / on your own / by yourself / lonely / lonealone / on your own / by yourself / lonely / lone
    • Alone, and on your own/by yourself (which are less formal and are the normal phrases used in spoken English), describe a person or thing that is separate from others. They do not mean that the person is unhappy:
      • I like being alone in the house.
      • I’m going to London by myself next week.
      • I want to finish this on my own (= without anyone’s help).
    • Lone/​solitary/​single mean that there is only one person or thing there; lone and solitary may sometimes suggest that the speaker thinks the person involved is lonely:
      • a lone jogger in the park
      • long, solitary walks
    • Lonely (North American English also lonesome) means that you are alone and sad:
      • a lonely child
      • Sam was very lonely when he first moved to New York.
      It can also describe places or activities that make you feel lonely:
      • a lonely house
  2. without help
    • Are you sure you did this exercise by yourself?
(all) to yourself/yourselves
  1. for only you to have or use; not shared
    • I'm going to be away next week so you'll have the office to yourself.
See yourself in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee yourself in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
Check pronunciation: yourself

name: do-it-yourself
content:
do-it-yourself

noun
 
/ˌduː ɪt jəˈself/
 
/ˌduː ɪt jərˈself/
(abbreviation DIY)
[uncountable] (especially British English)
jump to other results
  1. the activity of making, repairing or decorating things in the home yourself, instead of paying somebody to do it
    • The materials you need are available from any good do-it-yourself store.
See do-it-yourself in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: do-it-yourself
matches: take it on/upon yourself to do something
find it in your heart/yourself to do something
relatives: take it on/upon yourself to do something
find it in your heart/yourself to do something
take it on/upon yourself to do something
find it in your heart/yourself to do something

name: do yourself up
content:
do yourself up

phrasal verb
jump to other results
do yourself up
(also get done up)
  1. (informal) to make yourself more attractive by putting on make-up, attractive clothes, etc.
    • She did herself up in a white evening gown and diamonds.
    • Get done up in the costume of your favourite movie character and strut your stuff.

name: beat yourself up
content:
beat yourself up

phrasal verb
jump to other results
beat yourself up (about/over something)
(North American English also beat up on yourself (about/over something))
  1. (informal) to blame yourself too much for something
    • Look, there's no need to beat yourself up over this.

name: bury yourself in
content:
bury yourself in

phrasal verb
jump to other results
bury yourself in something
  1. to give all your attention to something
    • Since she left, he's buried himself in his work.
  2. to go to or be in a place where you will not meet many people
    • She buried herself in the country to write a book.

name: come to yourself
content:
come to yourself

phrasal verb
jump to other results
come to yourself
  1. (old-fashioned) to return to your normal state

name: dig yourself in
content:
dig yourself in

phrasal verb
jump to other results
dig yourself in
  1. (of soldiers) to protect yourself against an attack by making a safe place in the ground

name: keep to yourself
content:
keep to yourself

phrasal verb
jump to other results
keep (yourself) to yourself
  1. to avoid meeting people socially or becoming involved in their affairs
    • Nobody knows much about him; he keeps himself very much to himself.
keep something to yourself
  1. to not tell other people about something
    • I'd be grateful if you kept this information to yourself.
    • Kindly keep your opinions to yourself in future!

name: lose yourself in
content:
lose yourself in

phrasal verb
jump to other results
lose yourself in something
  1. to become so interested in something that it takes all your attention

name: pick yourself up
content:
pick yourself up

phrasal verb
jump to other results
pick yourself up
  1. to stand up again after you have fallen
    • He just picked himself up and went on running.
    • (figurative) She didn't waste time feeling sorry for herself—she just picked herself up and carried on.

name: put yourself out
content:
put yourself out

phrasal verb
jump to other results
put yourself out (for somebody)
  1. (informal) to make a special effort to do something for somebody
    • Please don't put yourself out on my account.
nearBys: put yourself up for phrasal verb

name: rid yourself of
content:
rid yourself of

phrasal verb
jump to other results
rid yourself of somebody/something
  1. (formal) to make yourself free from somebody/something that is annoying you or causing you a problem
    • to rid yourself of guilt
    • He wanted to rid himself of the burden of the secret.
    Extra Examples
    • I cannot rid myself of the fear of running short of money.
    • She tried to rid herself of her guests.

name: tart yourself up
content:
tart yourself up

phrasal verb
jump to other results
tart yourself up
  1. (informal) (especially of a woman) to make yourself more attractive by putting on nice clothes, jewellery, make-up, etc.
    • She was in her bedroom tarting herself up for the party.

name: avail yourself of
content:
avail yourself of

phrasal verb
jump to other results
avail yourself of something
(also Indian English, Irish English avail of something)
  1. (formal) to make use of something, especially an opportunity or offer
    • Guests are encouraged to avail themselves of the full range of hotel facilities.
    • (Irish English) Ireland's EU membership allows musicians to avail of opportunities to play throughout Europe.

name: cover yourself up
content:
cover yourself up

phrasal verb
jump to other results
cover up | cover yourself up
  1. to put on clothes or more clothes

name: devote yourself to
content:
devote yourself to

phrasal verb
jump to other results
devote yourself to somebody/something
  1. to give most of your time, energy, attention, etc. to somebody/something
    • She devoted herself to her career.
    • She devoted herself entirely to writing.

name: fend for yourself
content:
fend for yourself

phrasal verb
jump to other results
fend for yourself
  1. to take care of yourself without help from anyone else
    • His parents agreed to pay the rent for his apartment but otherwise left him to fend for himself.
    • The fox was released into the wild when it was old enough to fend for itself.
    • The children were left to fend for themselves.
    • We can let our guests fend for themselves.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverb + fend for
    • be able to
    • be left to
    • have to
    • …
    See full entry

name: fling yourself at
content:
fling yourself at

phrasal verb
jump to other results
fling yourself at somebody
  1. (informal, disapproving) to make it too obvious to somebody that you want to have a sexual relationship with them

name: get above yourself
content:
get above yourself

phrasal verb
jump to other results
get above yourself
  1. (especially British English) to have too high an opinion of yourselfTopics Opinion and argumentc2

name: get over yourself
content:
get over yourself

phrasal verb
jump to other results
get over yourself
  1. (informal) to stop thinking that you are so important; to stop being so serious
    • Just get over yourself and stop moaning!
    • He needs to grow up a bit and get over himself.

name: hire yourself out
content:
hire yourself out

phrasal verb
jump to other results
hire yourself out (to somebody)
  1. to arrange to work for somebody
    • He hired himself out to whoever needed his services.
